name: First Principles
description: The practice of actively questioning every assumption you think you 'know' about a given problem or scenario and then creating new knowledge and solutions from scratch.
example: Elon Musk reasoning that battery packs are expensive due to the market price, but the material cost is low, so he decided to make them himself.

name: Second-Order Thinking
description: Thinking about the consequences of the consequences. First-order thinking is looking at the immediate result of an action. Second-order thinking is looking at the result of that result.
example: First order: 'I'm hungry, I'll eat this chocolate cake.' Second order: 'If I eat this cake, I'll crash in an hour and feel sluggish for my meeting.'

name: Occam's Razor
description: The principle that when presented with competing hypotheses about the same prediction, one should select the solution with the fewest assumptions.
example: If you hear hoofbeats, think horses, not zebras (unless you are in the Serengeti).

name: Hanlon's Razor
description: Never attribute to malice that which is adequately explained by stupidity (or negligence).
example: Ensure you don't burn bridges with a colleague who missed a deadline; they likely just forgot rather than trying to sabotage you.

name: Pareto Principle
description: The 80/20 rule, which states that for many events, roughly 80% of the effects come from 20% of the causes.
example: 20% of the bugs cause 80% of the crashes. Fix those 20% first.

name: Map is not the Territory
description: The map of reality is not reality itself. Even the best maps are imperfect. That's because they are reductions of what they represent.
example: A financial model (map) might predict growth, but a sudden pandemic (territory) changes the reality regardless of the model.

name: Inversion
description: The practice of thinking through problems in reverse. Instead of asking how to do something, ask how to not do it.
example: Instead of asking 'How can I be happy?', ask 'What makes me miserable?' and avoid those things.

name: Circle of Competence
description: The subject area which matches a person's skills or expertise. You should play games where you have the aptitude and stay within your circle.
example: Warren Buffett investing only in businesses he understands (e.g., Coca-Cola) and avoiding tech stocks during the dot-com bubble.

name: Probabilistic Thinking
description: The ability to estimate the likelihood of any specific outcome coming to pass. It is the opposite of deterministic thinking.
example: Instead of saying 'We will launch on time', say 'There is an 85% chance we will launch on time based on current velocity.'

name: Sunk Cost Fallacy
description: The tendency to continue with an endeavor we've invested money, effort, or time into, even if the current costs outweigh the benefits.
example: Sitting through a terrible movie just because you paid for the ticket.

name: Compound Interest
description: The addition of interest to the principal sum of a loan or deposit, or in other words, interest on interest. Applies to habits and learning too.
example: Reading 20 pages a day seems small, but over a year it's 30 books, which creates a massive knowledge advantage.

name: Bayesian Updating
description: The process of updating the probability for a hypothesis as more evidence or information becomes available.
example: You think it will rain (50%). You see dark clouds (New Evidence). You update your belief to 80%.

name: Feedback Loops
description: A system where outputs of a system are circled back and used as inputs. Can be positive (amplifying) or negative (stabilizing).
example: Microphone screeching (Positive Feedback loop) vs Thermostat (Negative Feedback loop).

name: Critical Mass
description: The minimum amount of something required to start or maintain a venture.
example: A social network needs a critical mass of users before it becomes useful to anyone.

name: Activation Energy
description: The minimum quantity of energy that the reacting species must possess in order to undergo a specified reaction.
example: The hardest part of writing is writing the first sentence. Once started, the activation energy is overcome.

name: Leverage
description: Using a small amount of input to gain a large amount of output.
example: Using software (code) to serve millions of users with zero marginal cost of replication.

name: Scarcity
description: The limited availability of a commodity, which may be in demand in the market or by the commons.
example: limited time offers create a sense of scarcity that drives sales.

name: Structural/Systemic Bias
description: The tendency of a system to produce results that are skewed in favor of or against one group of people compared to another.
example: Algorithms trained on historical hiring data may replicate the bias against hiring women for technical roles.

name: Reason from First Principles
description: Breaking a problem down to the basic elements and then reassembling it from the ground up.
example: SpaceX reducing the cost of rockets by looking at the raw material cost of aluminum and fuel rather than the market price of rockets.

name: Regret Minimization Framework
description: Projecting yourself to age 80 and asking, 'Will I regret not doing this?'
example: Jeff Bezos quitting his job to start Amazon because he knew he would regret not trying, but wouldn't regret failing.

name: Data Sovereignty
description: The principle that a community or individual has the right to own, control, and govern the collection, application, and use of their data.
example: BlaqVox returning data power to the community by monitoring government APIs directly rather than relying on curated reports.

name: Community Intelligence
description: The collective insight generated when local residents, activists, and data analysts collaborate to identify and mitigate threats in real-time.
example: Aggregating ACLU civil rights cases with real-time threat detection to protect target communities in Seattle, Chicago, and Atlanta.
